'''Silver''' is a [[graphic novel]] series by American writer and artist [[Stephan Franck]].<ref>https://www.stephanfranck.com/</ref> It follows the adventures of James Finnigan, a [[Pulp era]] [[conman]] who teams up with Rosalynd "Sledge" Van Helsing to steel a mythical treasure hidden in [[Dracula]]'s castle.<ref>https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/silver-comic-book-end-crowdfunded-fourth-volume-1115226</ref> The first book in the series was nominated for the 2014 [[Russ Manning Award]].<ref>https://www.cbr.com/nominees-announced-for-2014-russ-manning-award/</ref> The four books in the series were released from 2014 to 2018.
== Books == === Plot === The plot of ''Silver'' spans 4 volumes. It is told through the point of view of James Finnigan, whose [[narration]] guides the reader through the story.
'''''Silver Volume 1<ref>https://previewsworld.com/Catalog/SEP141231</ref>''''': ''Silver'' begins in 1931 in New York city. We meet James Finnigan, who is an ethically challenged master-thief, and his partners in crime Mullins and Brantley, as they rob the mysterious Harker foundation. What was supposed to be their last job turns into a narrow escape from the FBI, and Finnigan loses the team’s retirement money. However, Finnigan discovers a mysterious ancient silver bar, and the late Jonathan Harker's secret ledger, which discloses the existence of a fabulous treasure made of silver, hidden away in Dracula's castle.<ref>https://nerdist.com/you-need-to-read-this-crowdfunded-comic-about-the-plot-to-steal-draculas-silver/ </ref> Aware that he might be in over his head, Finnigan seeks the help of Rosalynd “Sledge” Van Helsing, grand-daughter of Abram Van Helsing, and Tao, a ten year old boy with the gift of second sight.
'''''Silver Volume 2<ref>https://www.previewsworld.com/Catalog/OCT151372</ref>''''': The team boards the Orient Express, which is filled with Vampires on their way to Dracula’s castle. Romantic tension builds between Finnigan and Sledge, but she may have an ulterior motive for being on the team. It also becomes clear that Tao needs a role-model in Finnigan...something that the con man is not able to provide. Nonetheless, while constantly on the verge of disaster, the team succeeds in putting the heist in motion. As the team reaches the castle, and we discover a powerful, but broken Dracula, AKA Drah-Khan, who never recovered from the loss of Mina Harker. We also meet Lillian Duvalier, a cruel and ambitious vampire princess whose own agenda adds even more volatility to the situation.
'''''Silver Volume 3<ref>https://www.previewsworld.com/Catalog/MAR181559</ref>''''': The long con progresses, but Tao is shaken by a close brush with death, and Finnigan grows concerned that the kid might be shakier than he thought. Meanwhile, Sledge is having increasing difficulty containing her hatred for the undead. When Lillian goes out with a small party to raid a local village, Sledge goes rogue and launches after them. Out of options, Finnigan follows. Sledge manages to dispatches several vampires, including Lillian’s personal maids, but fails to save a couple of babies kidnapped by Lillian. Finn confronts Sledge but can’t seem to get through to her. Hoping to rescue the babies, Sledge carries on a desperate attempt on Drah-Khan life. The entire plan collapses. As the captured team awaits its fate, it is revealed that Lillian has succeeded in moving Drah-Khan past Mina and any hope for redemption her memory might represent. Drah-Khan and Lillian will marry when the clock strikes midnight, and sanctify their union by drinking the blood of the kidnapped babies.
'''''Silver Volume 4<ref>https://previewsworld.com/Catalog/SEP181703</ref>''''': In triumphant long-con fashion, we learn that the failure of the original plan and collapse of the team were fake-outs, all scripted and part of the actual plan. Using every single element of lore established earlier in the story against him, the team robs Drah-Khan of his treasure, while also saving the babies, and interrupting the wedding. As Drah-Khan's entire world falls apart, the team escapes on the train treasure on board, but Lilith shows up for a final confrontation with Sledge, and we discover that Tao was gravely wounded in the escape. Meanwhile, Drah-Khan figures out how the team escaped, and catches up to them to settled things once and for all.
=== Setting === The series takes place in a world inspired by [[Bram Stoker]]'s [[novel]] ''[[Dracula]]'', 40 years after the events of the novel. The story starts in a 1930's pulp-era New York City, and moves across Europe until it reaches Transylvania. Combining various elements of 1930's literature, adventure strips and cinema, the series can be described as an adventure story with supernatural elements, and as taking place in a meta pulp world.
=== Themes === The series deals with [[existential]] themes, such as "what does it mean to really feel alive?" It is examined through the point of view of vampires: ''"The are the dead masquerading as the living. Returning from the grave only to find a dark empty hole where their soul used to be. Incapable of love, friendship, or shedding a tear, they forever feel compelled to hoard some sort of treasure to which they become obsessively attached. It's always shiny, preferably Silver."''
== Adaptation == During [[New York Comic Con]] 2017, [[Deadline Hollywood]] reported that writer [[Andrew Cosby]] was attached to pen a movie adaptation.<ref>''[https://deadline.com/2017/10/silver-stephan-franck-andrew-cosby-graphic-novel-movie-1202182792/ Deadline:‘Silver’ Mettle For ‘Hellboy’ Scribe Andrew Cosby]''</ref>
== Reception == The series' reception has been generally positive. In its review of the 2018 [[Free Comic Book Day]] titles, ''[[NPR]]'''s Glen Weldon wrote ''“Writer/artist Stephan Franck is firing on all cylinders.... Stylish black-and-white art, and a smart, charmingly roguish point-of-view-character draw you in.”''<ref>https://www.npr.org/2018/05/03/603652979/free-comic-book-day-2018-a-guide-to-the-best-bets-and-the-best-avoided</ref>, and comic book reviews site ''[[Newsarama]]'' giving the first volume 10 stars out of 10<ref>https://www.newsarama.com/22752-best-shots-comic-reviews-all-new-captain-america-1-batman-36-more.html</ref>.

{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox sportsperson | name = | image = Spyridon Louis 1896.jpg | image_size = | caption = Spyridon Louis in 1896 | nickname = | birth_date = 12 January 1873{{cn|date=October 2018}} | birth_place = [[Marousi]], Greece | death_date = 26 March 1940 (aged 67) | death_place = Marousi, Greece | alma_mater = | height = | weight = | sport = Athletics | event = [[Marathon]] | club = | pb = 2:58:50 (1896) | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry| {{flagIOC|GRE|1896 Summer}}}} {{MedalCompetition | [[Olympic Games]]}} {{MedalGold | [[1896 Summer Olympics|1896 Athens]] | [[Athletics at the 1896 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon|Marathon]]}} | show-medals = yes }} '''Spyridon Louis''' ({{lang-el|Σπυρίδων Λούης}} {{IPA-el|spiˈriðon ˈluis|}}, sometimes transliterated ''Spiridon Loues'';{{cite journal|first1=James P.|last1= Verinis|title=Spiridon Loues, the Modern ''Foustanéla'', and the Symbolic Power of ''Pallikariá'' at the 1896 Olympic Games"|journal=Journal of Modern Greek Studies|volume=23|issue=1|date=May 2005|pages=139–175|doi=10.1353/mgs.2005.0010|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/cgi-bin/access.cgi?uri=/journals/journal_of_modern_greek_studies/v023/23.1verinis.pdf |subscription=yes|via=Project MUSE}} 12 January 1873 – 26 March 1940), commonly '''Spyros Louis''' (Σπύρος Λούης), was a [[Greeks|Greek]] water-carrier who won the first modern-day [[Marathons at the Olympics|Olympic marathon]] at the [[1896 Summer Olympics]]. Following his victory, he was celebrated as a national hero.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/lo/spyros-louis-1.html|title=Spyros Louis at the Olympics|last=|first=|date=|website=Sports-Reference.com|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107020515/https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/lo/spyros-louis-1.html|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=3 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} A former soldier, Louis was encouraged to try out for the Olympics by his former commanding officer. After progressing through qualifying, he went on to win the inaugural Olympic marathon after placing first from seventeen competitors. Louis later became a police officer and a farmer. Outside of his athletics career, Louis was arrested for forgery, of which he was acquitted after spending a year in jail. ==Early life== Spyridon Louis was born in the town of [[Marousi]], north of [[Athens]], into a poor family. Louis's father sold mineral water in Athens, which at the time lacked a central water supply, and his son helped him by transporting it.{{Cite news|url=http://www.pappaspost.com/spyridon-louis-presents-hitler-with-olive-tree-from-olympia/|title=On This Day August 1, 1936: Spyridon Louis Presents Hitler with Olive Tree from Olympia|last=Pappas|first=Gregory|date=1 August 2016|work=The Pappas Post|access-date=3 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107024237/http://www.pappaspost.com/spyridon-louis-presents-hitler-with-olive-tree-from-olympia/|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|language=en-US|df=dmy-all}} == Preparation == After [[Pierre de Coubertin]]'s decision in 1894 to revive the [[Olympic Games]], preparations were made to organise the first modern Olympics in Athens. One of the races would be the marathon, an event which had never been held before. It had been suggested by Frenchman [[Michel Bréal]], who was inspired by the legend of the messenger [[Pheidippides]], who had run from [[Marathon, Greece|Marathon]] to Athens to announce the Athenian victory in the [[Battle of Marathon]]—and then dropped dead.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1896/ATH/mens-marathon.html|title=Athletics at the 1896 Athina Summer Games: Men's Marathon|last=|first=|date=|website=Olympics at Sports-Reference.com|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170702165141/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1896/ATH/mens-marathon.html|archive-date=2 July 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=20 October 2017|df=dmy-all}} The Greeks were very enthusiastic about this new event and decided to hold qualifiers for the marathon. These races were started by Colonel Papadiamantopoulos, who Louis previously served under in the military.{{cite magazine |last1=Jones |first1=Hugh |title=Spiridon Louis |url=http://aims-worldrunning.org/articles/750-spiridon-louis.html |magazine=Distance Running |accessdate=28 September 2018 |date=23 February 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180928083029/http://aims-worldrunning.org/articles/750-spiridon-louis.html |archive-date=28 September 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} The first qualifying race—the first ever marathon race—was held on 22 March, and was won by [[Charilaos Vasilakos]] in 3 hours, 18 minutes.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14847407/daily_sitka_sentinel/|title=Today's Sports|last=|first=|date=10 March 1994|work=Daily Sitka Sentinel|access-date=2 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107014724/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14847407/daily_sitka_sentinel/|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|pages=7|df=dmy-all}} Louis participated in the second qualifying race, two weeks later, and placed fifth. Papadiamantopoulos, who knew of Louis's talent in running, had convinced him to try out.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.at/books?id=UZuKc4wUXGQC|title=The London Marathon|last=Bryant|first=John|date=15 December 2010|publisher=Random House|isbn=978-1-4464-1067-7|location=|pages=28|language=en|access-date=2 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107020309/https://books.google.at/books?id=UZuKc4wUXGQC|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The Olympic marathon was run on 10 April (or 29 March by the [[Julian calendar]] then in use in Greece). The Greek public had been very enthusiastic about the Games, but were disappointed in the fact that no [[track and field]] event had yet been won by a Greek competitor.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.at/books?id=Qb125O62NVQC|title=The Olympic Marathon|last=Martin|first=David E.|last2=Gynn|first2=Roger W. H.|date=2000|publisher=Human Kinetics|year=|isbn=978-0-88011-969-6|location=|pages=12–19|language=en|access-date=2 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107004226/https://books.google.at/books?id=Qb125O62NVQC|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The victory in the [[discus throw]], a classical Greek event, by the American [[Robert Garrett]] had been particularly painful. Because of its close connection with Greek history, the public yearned for the marathon to be won by one of their countrymen.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14847852/st_louis_postdispatch/|title=The Diskos Not So Hot.|last=|first=|date=11 July 1936|work=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|access-date=2 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107030041/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14847852/st_louis_postdispatch/|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|pages=11|df=dmy-all}} == The marathon race == In Marathon, Colonel Papadiamantopoulos gave the starting signal for the small field, consisting of seventeen athletes, thirteen of them representing Greece. The early leader of the race, which led over dusty dirt roads along which throngs of Greeks had gathered to watch, was the Frenchman [[Albin Lermusiaux]], who had placed third in the 1500 metres prior to the marathon.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14858014/the_sydney_morning_herald/|title=Berry's 50 Best|last=Berry|first=Kevin|date=21 December 1999|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=3 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107011736/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14858014/the_sydney_morning_herald/|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|pages=33|df=dmy-all}} In the town of [[Pikermi]], Louis is said to have made a stop at a local inn to drink a glass of wine. (Louis's grandson, also Spyridon Louis, has stated that this is incorrect; that his grandfather's girlfriend gave him half an [[Orange (fruit)|orange]] and shortly afterwards he "got a glass of cognac from his future father-in-law."{{Cite web|url=https://www.iaaf.org/news/news/a-marathon-legend-revisited|title=A Marathon legend revisited|last=|first=|date=27 August 2004|website=|publisher=[[International Association of Athletics Federations]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107010026/https://www.iaaf.org/news/news/a-marathon-legend-revisited|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=3 November 2017|df=dmy-all}}) After asking for the advantage of the other runners, he confidently declared he would overtake them all before the end.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.at/books?id=tnszj7AERkQC|title=Greece: The Peloponnese|last=Bostock|first=Andrew|date=May 2013|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=978-1-84162-451-8|location=|pages=199|language=en|access-date=3 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107012646/https://books.google.at/books?id=tnszj7AERkQC|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} After 26 km, Lermusiaux was exhausted and abandoned the race. The lead was taken over by [[Edwin Flack]], an Australian who won the 800 and 1500 m races. Louis slowly closed in on Flack. The Australian, not used to running long distances, collapsed a few kilometers onwards, giving Louis the lead.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14538752/the_age/|title=The 'Lion of Athens' conquers Olympics|last=|first=|date=14 April 1896|work=The Age|access-date=20 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171020191601/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14538752/the_age/|archive-date=20 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14858088/south_florida_sun_sentinel/|title=Rejoice! 21st-century messenger lives to tell his tale|last=|first=|date=18 July 2004|work=South Florida Sun Sentinel|access-date=3 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107010237/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14858088/south_florida_sun_sentinel/|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|pages=50|df=dmy-all}} During the race, there was tension among the Greek spectators when Flack was in first place. However, when news was delivered to the fans that Louis overtook the lead, the cry "Hellene, Hellene!" was taken up by rapturous spectators. Louis was greeted with cheers after entering the [[Panathenaic Stadium]] for the final part of the marathon. Louis ran with [[Constantine I of Greece|Crown Prince Constantine]] and [[Prince George of Greece]] during the last lap, finishing with a time of 2:58:50.{{cite news|title=In Greece, Everyone Has a Spyro Story|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14519234/the_los_angeles_times/|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=22 August 2004|page=103|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate=19 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171019221001/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14519234/the_los_angeles_times/|archive-date=19 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/the-original-marathon-man-50497.html|title=The original marathon man|last=|first=|date=7 August 2004|work=The Independent|access-date=20 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171020191522/http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/the-original-marathon-man-50497.html|archive-date=20 October 2017|dead-url=no|language=en-GB|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/olympics/293850/The-marathon-hero-fuelled-by-wine-and-spirit|title=The marathon hero fuelled by wine and spirit|last=Miller|first=David|date=6 January 2012|publisher=Express Newspapers|access-date=23 July 2018}} Louis's victory set off wild celebrations, as described in the official report of the Games:
Here the Olympionic Victor was received with full honour; the [[George I of Greece|King]] rose from his seat and congratulated him most warmly on his success. Some of the King’s aides-de-camp, and several members of the Committee went so far as to kiss and embrace the victor, who finally was carried in triumph to the retiring room under the vaulted entrance. The scene witnessed then inside the Stadion cannot be easily described, even strangers were carried away by the general enthusiasm.{{cite web|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1896/1896.pdf|title=Official Report of the 1896 Olympics|last=Lambros|first=Spyridon|last2=Politers|first2=N. G.|format=PDF|access-date=5 July 2018|page=209|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527211831/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1896/1896.pdf|archive-date=27 May 2008|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}
Adding to the celebrations, two more Greek runners entered the stadium to finish in second and third place. Third place finisher [[Spyridon Belokas]] was later found to have covered part of the course by carriage and was disqualified; third place was awarded to the Hungarian [[Gyula Kellner]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14858180/the_tampa_tribune/|title=Olympics 101|last=Fennelly|first=Martin|date=11 June 1992|work=The Tampa Tribune|access-date=3 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107020919/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14858180/the_tampa_tribune/|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|pages=32|df=dmy-all}} == After the Olympics == After his victory, Louis received gifts from many countrymen, ranging from jewellery to a lifelong free shave at a barber shop. It is unknown whether Louis accepted all these gifts, although he did take back home the carriage he had asked of the king. After the Olympics, Louis ended his athletic career to become a farmer and a police officer.{{Cite news|url=https://www.olympic.org/news/local-hero-louis-earns-cult-status-in-marathon|title=Local Hero Louis Earns Cult Status in Marathon|last=|first=|work=International Olympic Committee|access-date=20 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170327043424/https://www.olympic.org/news/local-hero-louis-earns-cult-status-in-marathon|archive-date=27 March 2017|dead-url=no|language=en|df=dmy-all}}[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-2003-1103-501, Berlin, Olympiade, Spyridon Louis, Kronprinz Paul.jpg|thumb|Spyridon Louis with Crown Prince (later king) [[Paul of Greece]] in [[Berlin]], during the [[1936 Summer Olympics]]]] In 1926, Louis was arrested on charges of falsifying military documents and was imprisoned. After spending more than a year in jail, he was acquitted.{{cite book|last1=Mallon|first1=Bill|last2=Heijamns|first2=Jeroen|title=Historical Dictionary of the Olympic Movement|page=209|edition=4th|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-7522-7|date=11 August 2011|url=https://books.google.at/books/about/Historical_Dictionary_of_the_Olympic_Mov.html?id=9mM0XzW03AcC|access-date=23 July 2018}} His last public appearance came in 1936, when he was invited to be a guest of honour by the organizers of the [[1936 Summer Olympics]], held in [[Berlin]]. After bearing the standard of the Greek team during the opening ceremonies, he was received by [[Adolf Hitler]] and offered him an olive branch from [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]], the birthplace of the Olympic Games, as a symbol of peace.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14858202/the_guardian/|title=Olympics Games Open To-Day: Athletes of 54 Nations to March Past Herr Hitler|last=|first=|date=31 July 1936|work=The Manchester Guardian|access-date=3 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107012946/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14858202/the_guardian/|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|location=Berlin, Germany|pages=14|df=dmy-all}} Louis recalled the moments after his victory: "That hour was something unimaginable and it still appears to me in my memory like a dream … Twigs and flowers were raining down on me. Everybody was calling out my name and throwing their hats in the air ..." Several months before the [[Italian invasion of Greece]], Louis died.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.at/books?id=vRokDwAAQBAJ|title=For the Love of Running: A Companion|last=Owen|first=Paul|date=11 May 2017|publisher=Summersdale Publishers Limited|year=|isbn=978-1-78685-163-5|location=|pages=1962|language=en|access-date=3 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107021522/https://books.google.at/books?id=vRokDwAAQBAJ|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In Greece, various sports establishments are named after Louis. These include the [[Olympic Stadium (Athens)|Olympic Stadium of Athens]] where the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] were held, as well as the road outside the stadium. The [[Jayne Mansfield]] movie ''[[It Happened in Athens]]'' is a heavily fictionalized take on Louis and the marathon,{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9D0CEEDD173CEF3BBC4D52DFB7678389679EDE|title=Screen: Olympic Games:'It Happened in Athens' at Local Theaters|date=15 November 1962|website=www.nytimes.com|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107020414/http://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9D0CEEDD173CEF3BBC4D52DFB7678389679EDE|archive-date=7 November 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=3 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} and his story is featured in the 1984 TV miniseries ''[[The First Olympics: Athens 1896]]''.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/20/arts/tv-view-squeezing-inspiration-from-the-1896-olympics.html |title=Squeezing Inspiration from the 1896 Olympics |first=John J. |last=O'Connor |author-link=John J. O'Connor (journalist) |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=20 May 1984 |access-date=23 May 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180524005936/https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/20/arts/tv-view-squeezing-inspiration-from-the-1896-olympics.html |archive-date=24 May 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} The expression in Greek: "''yinomai Louis''" (γίνομαι Λούης), translated as "to becοme Louis," means "tο disappear by running fast." == Breal's Silver Cup == The silver cup given to Louis at the first modern Olympic Games staged in Athens in 1896, was sold for £541,250 ($860,000) in London during a [[Christie's]] auction on 18 April 2012. The trophy, with a height of six inches, broke the auction record for Olympic memorabilia. The item was sold on the day Britain marked the 100 days' countdown to the 2012 London Olympics. Christie's called the auction "heated" and involved six bidders. The auctioneer later confirmed the buyer as the [[Stavros Niarchos Foundation]].Collett, Mike. (18 April 2012) [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/18/us-olympics-auction-idUSBRE83H0T320120418 "Marathon cup from 1896 sets Olympics auction record"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924163529/http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/18/us-olympics-auction-idUSBRE83H0T320120418 |date=24 September 2015 }}. ''Reuters''. Retrieved on 20 August 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-17758160|title=Olympic cup raises record amount|last=Minard|first=Jenny|date=18 April 2012|work=BBC News|access-date=19 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170527173159/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-17758160|archive-date=27 May 2017|dead-url=no|language=en-GB|df=dmy-all}} The cup is currently displayed at the [[Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center]], a project of the Stavros Niarchos Foundation, fulfilling the commitment of the foundation to make it available to the public and to share it with everyone, upon the project's completion. During the development of the project, the cup was temporarily displayed at the [[Acropolis Museum]] of Athens and the [[Olympic Museum]] in Lausanne, during a period that coincided with the International Marathon of Lausanne.Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center web site [https://www.snfcc.org/visitors-center/events/2016/08/spyros-louis%E2%80%99-br%C3%A9al-cup/ "Spyros Louis’ Breal Cup"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107025115/https://www.snfcc.org/visitors-center/events/2016/08/spyros-louis%E2%80%99-br%C3%A9al-cup/ |date=7 November 2017 }}{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/04/19/world/europe/olympic-breal-cup-auction/index.html|title=Iconic Olympic cup returns home to Greece for record price at auction|last=Glass|first=Nick|date=19 {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} The '''stop-question-and-frisk program''', or '''stop-and-frisk''', in [[New York City]], is a [[New York City Police Department]] practice of temporarily detaining, questioning, and at times searching civilians on the street for weapons and other contraband. This is what is known in other places in the United States as the [[Terry stop|''Terry'' stop]]. The rules for stop, question, and frisk are found in the state's [[criminal procedure law]] section 140.50, and are based on the decision of the [[US Supreme Court]] in the case of ''[[Terry v. Ohio]]''.
12,404 stops were made in 2016. The stop-and-frisk program has previously taken place on a much wider scale. Between 2003 and 2013, over 100,000 stops were made per year, with 685,724 people being stopped at the height of the program in 2011. The program became the subject of a [[racial profiling]] controversy. The vast majority, 90% in 2017, of those stopped were [[African-American]] or [[Latino]], most of whom were aged 14–24. Furthermore, 70% of all those stopped were later found to be innocent. The racial disparity persists even after controlling for precinct variability and race-specific estimates of crime participation. Research suggests that stop-and-frisk had few effects, if any, on violent and property crime rates in New York City.
==Legal background of stop-and-frisk== {{main|Stop and frisk|Consent search}}
{| class="wikitable" style="float:right; vertical-align: top; text-align: right; margin:.46em 0 0 .2em" |+ Stops by NYPD |- ! Year !! Stops |- | 2002 || 97,296 |- | 2003 || 160,851 |- | 2004 || 313,523 |- | 2005 || 398,191 |- | 2006 || 506,491 |- | 2007 || 472,096 |- | 2008 || 540,302 |- | 2009 || 581,168 |- | 2010 || 601,285 |- | 2011 || 685,724 |- | 2012 || 532,911 |- | 2013 || 191,851 |- | 2014 || 45,787 |- | 2015 || 22,565 |- | 2016 || 12,404 |- | 2017 || 10,861 |- |}
The [[United States Supreme Court]] made an important ruling on the use of stop-and-frisk in the 1968 case ''[[Terry v. Ohio]]'', hence why the stops are also referred to as [[Terry stop|''Terry'' stops]]. While frisks were arguably illegal, until then, a police officer could search only someone who had been arrested, unless a search warrant had been obtained. In the cases of ''Terry v. Ohio'', ''Sibron v. New York'', and ''Peters v. New York'', the Supreme Court granted limited approval in 1968 to frisks conducted by officers lacking probable cause for an arrest in order to search for weapons if the officer believes the subject to be dangerous. The Court's decision made suspicion of danger to an officer grounds for a "reasonable search."<ref>{{cite journal |last=Katz |first=Lewis R. |date=2004 |title=Terry v. Ohio at Thirty-Five: A Revisionist View |url=https://olemiss.edu/depts/ncjrl/pdf/katzMSLJ04.pdf | journal=Mississippi Law Journal |volume=74}}</ref>
In the early 1980s, if a police officer had reasonable suspicion of a possible crime, he or she had the authority to stop someone and ask questions. If, based on the subject's answers, the suspicion level did not escalate to probable cause for an arrest, the person would be released immediately. That was only a "stop-and-question". The "frisk" part of the equation did not come into play except on two cases: if possession of a weapon was suspected, or reasonable suspicion of a possible crime escalated to probable cause to arrest for an actual crime based on facts developed after the initial stop-and-question. That all changed in the 1990s, when [[CompStat]] was developed under then-Police Commissioner [[William Bratton]]. High-ranking police officials widely incorporated the "stop, question and frisk".<ref>"The Real History of Stop-and-frisk ". ''NY Daily News''. Ed. Ernie Naspretto. 3 June 2012. Web. 06 May 2014.</ref>
Use of stop-and-frisk is often associated with [[Broken windows theory|"broken windows" policing]]. The "broken windows theory" is the theory that low-level crime and disorder creates an environment which encourages more serious crimes. Among the key proponents of the theory are [[George L. Kelling]] and William Bratton, who was Chief of the [[New York City Transit Police]] from 1990 to 1992 and Commissioner of the [[New York City Police Department]] from 1994 to 1996. Mayor [[Rudy Giuliani]] hired Bratton for the latter job and endorsed broken windows policing. Giuliani and Bratton presided over an expansion of the New York police department and a crackdown on low-level crimes, including [[fare evasion]], [[public drinking]], [[public urination]], [[graffiti]] artists, and "[[squeegee men]]" (who had been wiping windshields of stopped cars and aggressively demanding payment).<ref>{{cite web|last=Editors |first=The |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/352533/stop-and-frisk-works-editors |title=Stop-and-Frisk Works |work=National Review |date=July 2, 2013 |accessdate=December 20, 2013}}</ref>
Bratton and Kelling argue that stop-and-frisk has been wrongly conflated with broken windows policing.<ref name="brattonkelling">{{cite web|url=https://www.city-journal.org/html/why-we-need-broken-windows-policing-13696.html|title=Why we need Broken Windows policing|publisher=City Journal|author=William Bratton, George Kelling|date=December 2014|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> They argue that stop-and-frisk is a short-term tactic for preventing a potential crime, whereas broken windows policing is a long-term tactic that requires the police to engage with communities.
==Measurement of stop-and-frisk in New York City== In 2002, there were 97,296 "stop and frisk" stops made by New York police officers; 82.4% resulted in no fines or convictions. The number of stops increased dramatically in 2008 to over half a million, 88% of which did not result in any fine or conviction, peaking in 2011 to 685,724 stops, again with 88% resulting in no conviction. On average, from 2002 to 2013, the number of individuals stopped without any convictions was 87.6%.<ref>"Stop-and-Frisk Data." Nyclu.org. New York Civil Liberties Union, 2013. 10 Mar 2014.</ref>
Part of the stop-question-and-frisk program is executed under Operation Clean Halls, a program in which private property owners grant officers prior permission to enter a property for enforcement against criminal activity.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zeidman |first1=Steven |title=Whither the Criminal Court: Confronting Stops-and-Frisks |journal=Albany Law Review |date=2012 |volume=76 |issue=2 |url=http://www.law.cuny.edu/faculty/pedagogy/SZeidman-SSRN-id2259923-WHITHER-THE-CRIMINAL-COURT-CONFRONTING-STOPS-AND-FRISKS.pdf}}</ref>
Some NYPD officers have objected publicly to the department's use of stop-question-and-frisk paperwork as a [[performance metric]], which they claim encourages officers to overuse the practice and creates public hostility. Activists have accused the NYPD of encouraging stops through [[ticket quota|quotas]], which department representatives have denied. In the vast majority of cases, no evidence of wrongdoing is found, and the stopped person is let go.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bellin |first1=Jeffrey |title=The Inverse Relationship Between the Constitutionality and Effectiveness of New York City "Stop and Frisk" |journal=Faculty Publications - William & Mary Law School |url=https://scholarship.law.wm.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.com/&httpsredir=1&article=2745&context=facpubs |date=2014 |issue=1706}}</ref>
==Controversy regarding mass-use and claims of racial profiling== [[File:Silent march to end stop and frisk and racial profiling.jpg|thumb|right|Demonstrators protest racial bias in policing, marching to then-Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]]'s house on June 17, 2012]] New York police officer [[Adrian Schoolcraft]] made extensive recordings in 2008 and 2009, which documented orders from NYPD officials to search and arrest black people in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood. Schoolcraft, who brought accusations of misconduct to NYPD investigators, was transferred to a desk job and then involuntarily committed to a psychiatric hospital. In 2010, Schoolcraft sent his tapes to the ''Village Voice'', which publicized them in a series of reports. Schoolcraft alleges that the NYPD has retaliated against him for exposing information about the stop and frisk policy.<ref name=LongHays>Colleen Long and Tom Hays, "[http://www.policeone.com/legal/articles/2774108-Cop-who-made-tapes-accuses-NYPD-of-false-arrest/ Cop who made tapes accuses NYPD of false arrest: Adrian Schoolcraft made hundreds of hours of secret tapes while on duty]", ''Associated Press'', Police.com, October 9, 2010.</ref><ref name=NYPDtapes4>Graham Rayman, "[http://www.villagevoice.com/2010-06-15/news/adrian-school-craft-nypd-tapes-whistleblower/ NYPD Tapes 4: The WhistleBlower, Adrian Schoolcraft: He wanted his bosses to know about NYPD misconduct. So they put him in a mental ward]", ''Village Voice'', June 15, 2010</ref> The [[New York Civil Liberties Union]] (NYCLU), [[LatinoJustice PRLDEF]], and [[The Bronx Defenders]] filed a federal class action against this program.<ref name="guardianuk2">{{cite news|title=Lawsuit alleges NYPD violated civil rights by entering private buildings|first=Ryan|last=Devereaux|authorlink=|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/mar/28/nypd-lawsuit-civil-rights-bronx|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date = February 14, 2012|accessdate=March 29, 2012|location=London}}</ref>
In response to allegations that the program unfairly targets African-American and Hispanic-American individuals, then-Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] has stated that it is because African-Americans and Hispanic-Americans are more likely to be violent criminals and victims of violent crime.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Smiley |first1=Calvin John |title=From “brute” to “thug:” the demonization and criminalization of unarmed Black male victims in America |journal=Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment |date=2016 |volume=26 |issue=3-4 |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5004736/}}</ref>
On June 17, 2012, several thousand people marched silently down [[Manhattan]]'s [[Fifth Avenue]] from lower [[Harlem]] to Bloomberg's [[Upper East Side]] townhouse in protest of the stop-question-and-frisk policy. The mayor refused to end the program, contending that the program reduces crime and saves lives.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Coviello |first1=Decio |title=An Economic Analysis of Black-White Disparities in NYPD’s Stop and Frisk Program |journal=The Journal of Legal Studies |date=2015 |volume=44 |issue=2 |url=http://nicolapersico.com/files/stopfrisk.pdf}}</ref>
In early July 2012, stop-question-and-frisk protesters who videotaped police stops in New York City were targeted by police for their activism. A "wanted"-style poster hung in a police precinct headquarters, without any allegation of criminal activity, accused one couple of being "professional agitators" whose "purpose is to portray officers in a negative way and too {{sic}} deter officers from conducting their responsibilities."<ref name=wantedposter>{{cite news | title=NYPD Shames Activists By Hanging "Wanted" Poster With Their Photos, Address | url=http://gothamist.com/2012/07/02/nypd_shames_activists_by_hanging_wa.php | first=Christopher | last=Robbins | work=gothamist.com | date=July 2, 2012 | accessdate=July 5, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140123012251/http://gothamist.com/2012/07/02/nypd_shames_activists_by_hanging_wa.php | archivedate=January 23, 2014 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> Police officers later surveilled and recorded the exit of persons from a "stop stop-and-frisk" meeting held at the couple's residence, allegedly in response to an emergency call of loitering and trespass.<ref>{{ cite news | title='Professional Agitators' on NYPD 'Wanted' Flier Say Cops Are Watching Them | url=http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20120704/west-harlem/professional-agitators-on-nypd-wanted-flier-eyed-by-cops-activists-say | first=Jeff | last=Mays | work=DNAinfo.com | date=July 4, 2012 | accessdate=July 5, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120704205950/http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20120704/west-harlem/professional-agitators-on-nypd-wanted-flier-eyed-by-cops-activists-say | archivedate=July 4, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In October 2012, ''The Nation'' published an obscenity-filled audio recording that revealed two NYPD officers conducting a hostile and racially charged stop-and-frisk of an innocent teenager from Harlem. Following its upload, the recording soon turned viral, as it triggered outrage and "shed unprecedented light" on the practice of stop-and-frisk.<ref>{{Cite AV media |medium=Video |title=Teen Called "F***ing Mutt" in Stop-And-Frisk |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c1Dr-hMCy78 |publisher=The Young Turks |date=October 10, 2012}}</ref>
===Class-action lawsuit brought by ACLU=== In ''[[Floyd v. City of New York]]'', decided on August 12, 2013, US District Court Judge [[Shira Scheindlin]] ruled that stop and frisk had been used in an [[unconstitutional]] manner and directed the police to adopt a written policy to specify where such stops are authorized.<ref>{{cite report |title=Floyd Original Complaint |url=https://ccrjustice.org/sites/default/files/assets/Floyd_Complaint_08.01.31.pdf |publisher=Center for Constitutional Rights |date=January 31, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media | people=Vincent Warren, Executive Director of the Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) | date=March 18, 2014 | title=Color Coded Justice: The Legal Battle to End Stop and Frisk in New York City | medium=Video | publisher=University of Pittsburgh School of Law |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jBcSsrXw36Y}}</ref> Scheindlin appointed [[Peter L. Zimroth]], a former chief lawyer for the City of New York, to oversee the program.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gardiner |first=Sean |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324085304579008510786797006 |title=Judge Rules NYPD Stop-and-Frisk Practice Violates Rights - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date= |accessdate=August 12, 2013}}</ref> Mayor Bloomberg indicated that the city will appeal the ruling.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/13/nyregion/stop-and-frisk-practice-violated-rights-judge-rules.html?_r=0 | work=The New York Times | first=Joseph | last=Goldstein | title=Judge Rejects New York's Stop-and-Frisk Policy | date=August 12, 2013}}</ref> Scheindlin had denied pleas for a stay in her overthrow of the policing policy, saying that "Ordering a stay now would send precisely the wrong signal. It would essentially confirm that the past practices... were justified and based on constitutional police practices. It would also send the message that reducing the number of stops is somehow dangerous to the residents of this city."<ref>{{cite web |title=Motion to Stay Pending Appeal |url=https://ccrjustice.org/sites/default/files/assets/Floyd%20-%20Motion%20to%20Stay%20Pending%20Appeal%202nd%20Cir.pdf |publisher=Center for Constitutional Rights |date=September 23, 2013}}</ref>
On October 31, 2013, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] blocked the order requiring changes to the New York Police Department's stop-and-frisk program and removed Judge Shira Scheindlin from the case.<ref>{{cite web|title=On October 31, 2013, the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Shira Scheindlin blocked the order requiring changes to the New York Police Department's stop-and-frisk program and removed the judge from the case|url=http://www.myfoxny.com/story/23843622/federal-appeals-court-blocks-stop-frisk-ruling|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=October 31, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101174359/http://www.myfoxny.com/story/23843622/federal-appeals-court-blocks-stop-frisk-ruling|archivedate=November 1, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kalhan|first=Anil|title=The Appearance of Impropriety and Partiality|url=http://www.dorfonlaw.org/2013/11/the-appearance-of-impropriety-and.html|work=Dorf on Law|date=Nov 5, 2013}}</ref><ref name="KalhanGJLE">{{cite journal|last1=Kalhan|first1=Anil|title=Stop and Frisk, Judicial Independence, and the Ironies of Improper Appearances|journal=Georgetown Journal of Legal Ethics|date=2014|volume=27|issue=4|ssrn=2499983}}</ref> On November 9, 2013, the city asked a federal appeals court to vacate Scheindlin's orders.<ref>{{cite web|title=Attorneys for New York City asked a federal appeals court Saturday to vacate a judge's orders that require the police department to change its stop-and-frisk practice that critics argue unfairly targets minorities |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/nyc-moves-vacate-judges-stop-frisk-decisions-20840832|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=November 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kalhan|first=Anil|title=Lame Duck Litigation and the City of New York's "Double Game"|url=http://www.dorfonlaw.org/2013/11/lame-duck-litigation-and-city-of-new.html|work=Dorf on Law|date=Nov 9, 2013}}</ref> On November 22, 2013, the federal appellate court rejected the city's motion for a stay of the judge's orders.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press in New York |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/22/federal-appeals-court-upholds-rulings-stop-frisk-unconstitutional |title=Federal appeals court upholds rulings that stop-and-frisk is unconstitutional | World news |publisher=theguardian.com |date=2013-11-22 |accessdate=2014-03-04}}</ref>
On July 30, 2014, Southern District Court Judge Analisa Torres denied the police unions' motions to intervene and granted the proposed modification of the District Court's August 2013 remedial decision.<ref name=KalhanGJLE /><ref name="CCRJustive.org/files">{{cite web|url=http://www.ccrjustice.org/files/Floyd%20v%20City%20of%20New%20York%20-%20July%2030%202014%20Opinion%20and%20Order.pdf |format=PDF |title=David Floyd et al v. City of New York |website=Ccrjustice.org |accessdate=2016-06-03}}</ref> A week later, the City of New York filed a motion to withdraw its appeal.<ref name="CCRJustive.org/files"/> On August 13, 2014, the Second Circuit announced the cases will be argued on October 15, 2014.<ref name=KalhanGJLE /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ccrjustice.org/stopandfrisk |format=PDF |title=Log in facility |website=Ccrjustice.org |accessdate=2016-06-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20120328092707/http%3A//ccrjustice.org/stopandfrisk |archivedate=March 28, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} {{subscription required|date=June 2016}}</ref> On October 31, a three-judge panel on the Second Circuit unanimously ruled against the unions and allowed the city to proceed with its overhaul of the police department.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gay |first=Mara |url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/federal-court-greenlights-new-york-stop-and-frisk-overhaul-1414783716 |title=Appeals Court Greenlights New York Stop-and-Frisk Overhaul - WSJ |website=Online.wsj.com |date=2014-10-31 |accessdate=2016-06-03}}</ref>
===Settlement of lawsuit and political ramifications=== A record 685,724 stops were made under the program in 2011; however, the number of stops made has been reduced in every year since then. A major turning point was the 2013 court case ''[[Floyd v. City of New York]]'' and a subsequent NYPD mandate that requires officers to thoroughly justify the reason for making a stop.<ref name="mummolo">{{Cite journal|last=Mummolo|first=Jonathan|date=2017-12-06|title=Modern Police Tactics, Police-Citizen Interactions, and the Prospects for Reform|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/694393|journal=The Journal of Politics|pages=000–000|doi=10.1086/694393|issn=0022-3816}}</ref> In 2013, 191,558 stops were made.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.nyclu.org/content/stop-and-frisk-data | title = Stop-and-Frisk Data | publisher = [[New York Civil Liberties Union]] | accessdate = March 20, 2013 }}</ref>
Stop-and-frisk was an issue in the [[New York City mayoral election, 2013|2013 mayoral election]]. The race to succeed Bloomberg was won by Democratic Party candidate [[Bill de Blasio]], who had pledged to reform the stop-and-frisk program, called for new leadership at the NYPD, an inspector general, and a strong racial profiling bill.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.billdeblasio.com/issues/crime-fighting-public-safety |title=Bill de Blasio For New York: Rising Together - Safe Streets, Safe Neighborhoods |publisher=Billdeblasio.com |date= |accessdate=December 20, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112052142/http://www.billdeblasio.com/issues/crime-fighting-public-safety |archivedate=November 12, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The number of stops continued to decrease over the next two years. In August 2014, ''[[Newsweek]]'' reported while stop-and-frisk numbers were down, they still happen disproportionately in New York City's African-American and [[Latino Americans|Latino]] neighborhoods.<ref name=Newsweek>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/did-bill-de-blasio-keep-his-promise-reform-stop-and-frisk-266310 |title=Did Bill de Blasio Keep his Promise to Reform Stop-and-Frisk? |website=Newsweek.com |accessdate=2016-06-03}}</ref> In 2015, only 22,929 stops were made.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.nyclu.org/content/stop-and-frisk-data | title = Stop-and-Frisk Data | publisher = [[New York Civil Liberties Union]] | accessdate = March 20, 2013 }}</ref>
==The politics of stop-and-frisk==
=== Opposition === Opponents of the program have complained that it is [[racist]] and failed to reduce robbery, burglary, or other crime.
Manhattan Borough President [[Scott Stringer]] has argued that the program constitutes harassment of blacks and Latinos because it is disproportionately directed at them.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/24/nyregion/scott-stringer-manhattan-leader-criticizes-stop-and-frisk.html Borough President Seeks Limits on Stop-and-Frisk]</ref>
The NYC Bar Association casts doubt on whether police were applying the "reasonable suspicion" rule when making stops: "The sheer volume of stops that result in no determination of wrongdoing raise the question of whether police officers are consistently adhering to the constitutional requirement for reasonable suspicion for stops and frisks."<ref>[http://www2.nycbar.org/pdf/report/uploads/20072495-StopFriskReport.pdf New York City Bar Association report on the NYPD's stop-and-frisk policy]</ref>
In a January 2018 op-ed in the ''[[National Review]]'', conservative writer Kyle Smith said that the steep decline in New York City's crime rate since the reduction in the use of stop-and-frisk had shown him that he was wrong about stop-and-frisk; Smith had earlier argued that reducing stop-and-frisk would increase the crime rate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/455035/new-york-city-stop-and-frisk-crime-decline-conservatives-wrong|title=We Were Wrong about Stop-and-Frisk|work=National Review|access-date=2018-01-02|language=en}}</ref>
=== Support === Paul J. Browne, an NYPD spokesman, defended the practice, saying "stops save lives, especially in communities disproportionately affected by crime, and especially among young men of color who last year represented 90 percent of murder victims and 96 percent of shooting victims in New York City."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/24/nyregion/scott-stringer-manhattan-leader-criticizes-stop-and-frisk.html Borough President Seeks Limits on Stop-and-Frisk] NY Times, September 23, 2011</ref>
Then-mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] defended the aspect of stopping young black and Hispanic men at rates that "do not reflect the city’s overall census numbers", saying that "that the proportion of stops generally reflects our crime numbers does not mean, as the judge wrongly concluded, that the police are engaged in racial profiling; it means they are stopping people in those communities who fit descriptions of suspects or are engaged in suspicious activity."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/michael-bloomberg-stop-and-frisk-keeps-new-york-safe/2013/08/18/8d4cd8c4-06cf-11e3-9259-e2aafe5a5f84_story.html Michael Bloomberg: ‘Stop and frisk’ keeps New York safe] - By Michael R. Bloomberg - August 18, 2013 (on the ''Washington Post'' op-ed page)</ref>
[[Heather MacDonald]] denied that blacks are being stopped too often and claimed the opposite: "The actual crime rates reveal that blacks are being significantly understopped, compared with their representation in the city’s criminal population."<ref>[https://www.city-journal.org/html/distorting-truth-about-crime-and-race-10730.html Distorting the Truth About Crime and Race: The New York Times is at it again] - Heather Mac Donald - May 14, 2010</ref> NYC Police Commissioner [[Raymond Kelly]] wrote, "the statistics reinforce what crime numbers have shown for decades: that blacks in this city were disproportionately the victims of violent crime, followed by Hispanics. Their assailants were disproportionally black and Hispanic too."<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/opinion/nypd-minorities-no-article-1.1080920?pgno=1 The NYPD vs. minorities? No way] - NY Daily News op-ed column May 21, 2012</ref>
Stop-and-frisk became an issue in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], with [[Donald Trump]] attributing a nonexistent increase in murders in New York to the reduction of stop-and-frisk.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/27/opinion/campaign-stops/the-lies-trump-told.html|title=The Lies Trump Told|author=David Leonhardt|date=September 26, 2016|newspaper=NYT|access-date=September 27, 2016|location=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/28/nyregion/what-donald-trump-got-wrong-on-stop-and-frisk.html|title=What Donald Trump Got Wrong on Stop-and-Frisk|author=Jim Dwyer|date=September 27, 2016|newspaper=NYT|access-date=September 27, 2016|location=}}</ref>
===Advocates for a small-scale program=== Bratton and Kelling both argue that stop-and-frisk is a useful tool that must be used in moderation.<ref name="brattonkelling"/> In a joint article in late 2014, they wrote that a ''Terry'' stop is "one of the key means to detect and prevent crimes in progress" and "an important tool in street policing", while also supporting efforts to reduce its use.<ref name="brattonkelling"/> Bratton agreed it was causing tension with ethnic communities and that it was less needed in an era of lower crime.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/07/bill-bratton-stop-and-frisk-new-york|date=2013-12-07|accessdate=2018-01-09|title=Bill Bratton seeks good community relations to make stop-and-frisk work|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''}}</ref>
==Impact==
=== Crime === A 2012 study finds few effects of stop-and-frisk on robbery and burglary rates in New York between 2003 and 2010.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Rosenfeld|first=Richard|last2=Fornango|first2=Robert|date=2014-01-02|title=The Impact of Police Stops on Precinct Robbery and Burglary Rates in New York City, 2003-2010|journal=Justice Quarterly|volume=31|issue=1|pages=96–122|doi=10.1080/07418825.2012.712152|issn=0741-8825}}</ref> According to the ''Washington Post'' fact-checker, the claim that stop-and-frisk contributed to a decline in the crime rate is unsubstantiated.<ref name=":1">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2016/live-updates/general-election/real-time-fact-checking-and-analysis-of-the-first-presidential-debate/fact-check-trump-on-crime-statistics-and-stop-and-frisk/|title=Fact Check: Trump on crime statistics and stop-and-frisk|date=September 26, 2016|newspaper=Washington Post|location=|access-date=September 27, 2016|author=Michelle Lee}}</ref>
A 2016 study found no evidence that stop-and-frisk was effective. One of the authors of that study, [[Jeffrey Fagan]] of Columbia University, said that "you can achieve really very positive crime control, reductions in crime, if you do stops using those probable-cause standards. If you just leave it up to the officers, based on their hunches, then they have almost no effect on crime."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/09/22/donald-trump-claims-new-yorks-stop-and-frisk-policy-reduced-crime-the-data-disagree/ Donald Trump claims New York’s stop-and-frisk policy reduced crime. The data disagree.]</ref> Fagan "found stops based on probable cause standards of criminal behavior were associated with a 5–9 percent decline in NYC crime in census block groups."<ref>[https://poseidon01.ssrn.com/delivery.php?ID=661105029067075096079083120122110075036068033079045035081067023018024124121127117118096007116103015125020083109093104124101110006001026038048121002112112124126120066047075020003097004117114073091115101089113114003024118106008102111099095110088017069&EXT=pdf The Effects of Local Police Surges on Crimeand Arrests in New York City] February 11, 2016</ref>
Another 2016 study found that stop-and-frisk lowered crime, and that the size of the effect was "significant yet modest". The authors also noted that "the level of SQFs needed to produce meaningful crime reductions are costly in terms of police time and are potentially harmful to police legitimacy."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Weisburd|first1=David|last2=Wooditch|first2=Alese|last3=Weisburd|first3=Sarit|last4=Yang|first4=Sue-Ming|title=Do Stop, Question, and Frisk Practices Deter Crime?|journal=Criminology & Public Policy|date=February 2016|volume=15|issue=1|pages=31–56|doi=10.1111/1745-9133.12172}}</ref> A 2017 study also reported that stop-and-frisk was associated with modest crime reductions, and cautioned against drawing strong causal conclusions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rosenfeld|first1=Richard|last2=Fornango|first2=Robert|title=The Relationship Between Crime and Stop, Question, and Frisk Rates in New York City Neighborhoods|journal=Justice Quarterly|date=9 January 2017|pages=1–21|doi=10.1080/07418825.2016.1275748}}</ref>
A 2017 study in the ''[[The Journal of Politics|Journal of Politics]]'' found that the introduction of a mandate in 2013 that officers provide thorough justifications for stopping suspects led to far fewer stops, far fewer detainments of innocent people and increased the ratio of stops that ultimately produced evidence of the crime that the police stopped the suspect for.<ref name="mummolo"/>
=== Economy === One study, controlling for relevant factors, finds "that properties exposed to more intense Stop & Frisk activity sold for significantly lower price."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Friedman|first=Matthew|date=2015-08-14|title=Valuing Proactive Policing: A Hedonic Analysis of Stop & Frisk's Amenity Value|location=Rochester, NY|publisher=Social Science Research Network|ssrn=2695584}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Discrimination|Law enforcement|New York City}} * [[Carding (police policy)]], a Canadian equivalent * [[Civilian Complaint Review Board]] * [[Consent search]] * [[Crime in New York City]] * {{section link|Powers of the police in England and Wales|Search without arrest}} * [[Proactive policing]] * [[Reasonable suspicion]] * [[Sus law]], England and Wales * [[Terry stop]] * [[Terry v. Ohio]] * [[New York City Cabaret Law]]

{{Taxation}} Taxation in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] includes both federal and local taxes. Tax revenue in Bosnia and Herzegovina stood at 28.6% of GDP in 2013. Most important revenue sources include the [[income tax]], [[Social Security (Bosnia)|Social Security]] contributions, [[corporate tax]], and the [[value added tax]], which are all applied on the federal level.
Income tax is applied on a flat tax rate of 10% on income from both employment, interest, royalties, and capital gains.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/global/Documents/Tax/dttl-tax-bosniaandherzegovinahighlights-2014.pdf|title = Deloitte - Income Tax|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Social Security apply to most employment income. The employee pay 33% of gross salary, while the employer contribute 10.5% in addition.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.kpmg.com/Global/en/IssuesAndInsights/ArticlesPublications/thinking-beyond-borders/documents/bosnia-herzegovina.pdf|title = Social security - KPMG|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Value-added tax in Bosnia is 17% as standard rate.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.kpmg.com/Global/en/services/Tax/regional-tax-centers/european-union-tax-centre/Documents/eu-country-profiles/2013-bosnia-herzegovina.pdf|title = VAT - KPMG|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Various Goods are services are exempt from VAT, including medical care, posting services, financial services, education and various smaller occasions.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://eurofast.eu/dev1/phocadownload/articles/the%20key%20features%20of%20the%20vat%20system%20in%20bosnia%20and%20herzegovina.pdf|title = VAT Bosnia|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
Stamp duties apply on various verifications of public documents. For incorporation purposes, stamp duties may range from EUR 50 to EUR 100.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.kpmg.com/Global/en/services/Tax/Documents/eu-country-profiles/2012-bosnia-herzegovina.pdf|title = KPMG Bosnia|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Corporate Taxes in Bosnia is levied at a flat rate of 10%.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.kpmg.com/Global/en/IssuesAndInsights/ArticlesPublications/Documents/corporate-indirect-tax-rate-survey-2014.pdf|title = Corporate Tax Card|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== History == Taxation in Bosnia has shifted over time, depending on the government that was in power. During the Yugoslav era taxation was similar to that of the rest of the Soviet, which typically relied heavily on a [[turnover tax]] and taxes paid by enterprises. In case of this two taxes they respectively made up 50% and 5% of total revenue in 1963.<ref>{{Cite book|url = https://books.google.dk/books?id=sVdADrBBo3MC&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26&dq=yugoslavia+taxation&source=bl&ots=HdasFrF4qn&sig=U-67C7gQXYeHi--UvR_HE3dF_64&hl=da&sa=X&ei=0t0CVI7VGoj8ywPuo4KABg&ved=0CGkQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=yugoslavia%20taxation&f=false|title = The Market-Planned Economy of Yugoslavia|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{refimprove|date=June 2012}}
'''Taxation in Estonia''' consists of state and local taxes. A relatively high proportion of government revenue comes from [[consumption tax]]es whilst revenue from [[capital gains tax|capital taxes]] is one of the lowest in the [[European Union]].
==Land Value Tax== [[Estonia]] levies a [[Land Value Tax]] which is used to fund local municipalities. It is a state level tax, but 100% of the revenue is used to fund Local Councils. The rate is set by the Local Council within the limits of 0.1-2.5%. It is one of the most important sources of funding for municipalities.<ref name="Land Tax Reform">{{cite web|title=Land Taxation Reform in Estonia|url=http://aysps.gsu.edu/isp/files/ISP_CONFERENCES_PROPERTY_TAX_06_TIITS_PAPER.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806011749/http://aysps.gsu.edu/isp/files/ISP_CONFERENCES_PROPERTY_TAX_06_TIITS_PAPER.pdf|archivedate=2010-08-06|df=}}</ref>
The Land Value Tax is levied on the value of the land only, improvements are not considered. Very few [[Tax exemption|exemptions]] are considered on the land tax and even public institutions are subject to the land value tax. Land that is the site of a church is exempt, but other land held by religious institutions is not exempt.<ref name="Land Tax Reform" />
The tax has contributed to a high rate (~90%)<ref name="Land Tax Reform" /> of owner-occupied residences within Estonia, compared to a rate of 67.4% in the [[United States]].
== Natural persons income tax == Estonia natural person [[income tax]] is considered to be [[Proportional tax|proportional]], but, due to basic exemption, it is actually [[Progressive tax|progressive]]. Standard [[Tax rate|rate]] for [[Natural person|natural persons]] in year 2015 is 20% (down from 21% in 2014).<ref name="Tax rates in Estonia">{{cite web|title=Tax rates in Estonia|url=http://www.emta.ee/index.php?id=3274|accessdate=2012-06-18}}</ref> A basic [[Tax exemption|exemption]] is granted, which is increased upon provision of maintenance to a child, in event of pensions, in event of compensation for accident at work or occupational disease. Additionally a number of expenses are [[Tax deduction|deductible]]: housing loan interests, training expenses, gifts, donations, contributions to a voluntary/mandatory funded pension and unemployment insurance, social security payments mandatory in a foreign state. Amount of deductible housing loan interest, training expenses, gifts and donations is limited – in 2011 the limit was 3196 euros but no more than 50% of the taxpayer's income during the same period of taxation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Taxpayer's assistant: declaration of income|url=http://www.emta.ee/index.php?id=29292|accessdate=2012-06-18}}</ref>
There is no [[capital gains tax]] but gains from transfer of securities or other financial assets are subject to standard income tax. Since 2011 a new system has been in place, which allows natural persons to defer the tax liability created on income received from financial assets until the time of taking the income into use, by using an investment account for this purpose. An investment account is just an ordinary monetary account with an obligation to record all money transfers. For attaining an objective by means of an investment account income received from the financial assets must be transferred to an investment account without delay. A taxable amount shall be created when the disbursements made from all investment accounts exceed the balance of contributions in all investment accounts after the disbursement.<ref>{{cite web|title=Taxation of income received from financial assets|url=http://www.emta.ee/index.php?id=31672|accessdate=2012-06-18}}</ref>
== Social tax and mandatory insurance payments == Salaries paid to employees are subject to # Social tax # [[Unemployment insurance]] premiums # Funded pension payment Social tax rate stands at 33%. The same rate is applied to fringe benefits that employer provides to employees. Unemployment insurance premiums are paid by both employer and employee: 2,8% is withheld is of the employee gross salary and 1,4% is paid by employers of monthly gross salaries. In 2012, a rate of a funded pension payment is 2% of the gross salary of a resident employee and are withheld by employer.<ref name="Tax rates in Estonia"/>
== Corporations/legal persons income tax == [[Legal person|Legal persons]] income tax rate is 20% in the year 2015. However, the system of [[Corporate tax|corporate earnings taxation]] currently in force in Estonia is a unique system, which shifts the moment of corporate taxation from the moment of earning the profits to the moment of their distribution. In other words, earning profits in itself does not bring income tax liability, which arises only when earned profit is distributed to shareholders. In case profit distributed to shareholders originates from dividends received from subsidiary company or from permanent establishment corporation has in other country, then profit distribution is tax exempt. Estonia does not have [[withholding tax]] on dividends paid. Nevertheless, Distributed profits are taxed at a rate of 20%.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.emta.ee/eng/business-client/income-expenses-supply-profits/taxation-profits-estonia|title=Taxation of profits in Estonia {{!}} Estonian Tax and Customs Board|website=www.emta.ee|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref>
== Value added tax == From 1 July 2009, the standard VAT tax rate in Estonia has been 20% and a reduced rate of 9%. A small number of goods and services are not taxed. Estonian VAT system is based on EU Council directive 2006/112/EC and its basic principles are the same as in other [[Member state of the European Union|EU countries]]. As of 2018 annual turnover threshold for mandatory registration as VAT liable person is 40 000 euros.<ref>{{cite web|title=Value added tax law|url=https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/518122017005/consolide}}</ref>
== Tax administration in Estonia == Responsibility for administering taxes lies on the [[Tax and Customs Board]]. Majority of tax declarations are presented via internet: for example, in the year 2012 94,2% of all natural persons income tax declaration were presented using the Internet. Percentages for VAT and customs declarations are even higher.
== Other taxes == Taxes applied in Estonia that were not mentioned previously: # Excises on electricity, alcohol, tobacco, fuel and packaging. # Customs duties. # Tax on gambling # Tax on heavy vehicles.
==External links== * [http://www.emta.ee/eng Estonia Tax and Customs Board]
